stem: The nurse is assessing a 9-month-old infant during a routine well-child visit. Based on the assessment findings and provided medical record, indicate which developmental milestones are expected for this age.

tabs.title: Nurses' Notes
tabs.content:
14:00 Nurse Amy SBAR Note:

Situation: Baby David, 9 months old, here for routine check-up. Mom, Sarah, reports general good health. No acute concerns today.

Background: Born full-term, uneventful pregnancy and delivery. Immunizations up-to-date. Breastfed until 6 months, now on purees and some finger foods. Has been meeting developmental milestones according to parent report at previous visits. No known allergies.

Assessment: Alert and interactive infant. Weight and height within normal range for age (see vitals). Auscultation of heart and lungs clear. Abdomen soft, non-tender. Moves all extremities equally. Noted to transfer objects from one hand to another during assessment. Unable to sit unsupported for more than a few seconds. Does not crawl, scoots on bottom. Responds to own name. Babbles sounds like 'mama' and 'dada'.

Recommendation: Continue current feeding plan. Encourage tummy time and floor play to promote crawling. Discuss anticipatory guidance regarding age-appropriate safety measures and developmental expectations. Schedule next well-child visit in 3 months. Address parental concerns and provide resources as needed.

tabs.title: Vital Signs
tabs.content:
14:05 Vitals:

Weight: 20 lbs (9.1 kg) - 50th percentile
Height: 28 inches (71.1 cm) - 50th percentile
Heart Rate: 100 bpm
Respiratory Rate: 24 breaths/min
Temperature: 98.6°F (37°C) - Axillary

tabs.title: Lab Results
tabs.content: No lab results available for this visit.

tabs.title: Physical Exam
tabs.content:
General: Alert and active infant in no acute distress.
Skin: Warm, dry, and intact. No rashes or lesions noted.
HEENT: Head normocephalic. Fontanelles open and flat. Eyes clear, PERRL. Ears normal appearance. Nose patent. Oral mucosa pink and moist. No lesions noted.
Cardiovascular: Regular rate and rhythm, no murmurs.
Respiratory: Clear to auscultation bilaterally. No wheezes or crackles.
Abdomen: Soft, non-tender, non-distended. Bowel sounds present in all four quadrants.
Musculoskeletal: Moves all extremities equally. Muscle tone appropriate for age. Hips stable. Spine straight.
Neurological: Age appropriate reflexes present. Responds to stimuli. Cranial nerves intact.

tabs.title: Care Plan
tabs.content:
Care Plan:

1. Routine well-child visit.
2. Administer scheduled immunizations per CDC guidelines.
3. Provide anticipatory guidance regarding nutrition, safety, and development.
4. Schedule follow-up appointment in 3 months.

tabs.title: MAR
tabs.content:
Medication Administration Record:

Vaccine | Dose | Route | Site | Date/Time
---|---|---|---|---
Diphtheria, Tetanus, Pertussis (DTaP) | 0.5 mL | IM | Left Thigh | Today
Hemophilus influenzae type b (Hib) | 0.5 mL | IM | Right Thigh | Today
Pneumococcal Conjugate (PCV13) | 0.5 mL | IM | Left Thigh | Today
Inactivated Poliovirus (IPV) | 0.5 mL | SQ | Right Thigh | Today

rows.text: Transfers objects from one hand to the other

rationale.correct: The correct selections accurately reflect the expected developmental milestones for a 9-month-old infant. Assessing and monitoring these milestones helps identify potential developmental delays and ensure appropriate interventions.
rationale.incorrect: The incorrect selections do not accurately reflect the expected developmental milestones for a 9-month-old infant. Understanding typical development is essential for providing proper anticipatory guidance and early intervention.

answerBreakdown.rationale: A 9-month-old infant is typically able to sit unsupported for brief periods. This demonstrates improved balance and muscle control.

answerBreakdown.text: Transfers objects from one hand to the other
answerBreakdown.rationale: The ability to transfer objects between hands is an expected milestone at 9 months, indicating developing fine motor skills and hand-eye coordination.

While some infants may crawl on their bellies (commando crawl), by 9 months, most infants are transitioning to crawling on their hands and knees or scooting. Crawling forward on the belly as the primary means of locomotion is less common at this age. Note from SBAR that the patient scoots on bottom rather than crawls on hands and knees.

Pulling to stand is a milestone typically achieved around 8-10 months. While some 9-month-olds may be attempting to pull to stand, it is not yet a consistently expected milestone. The Nurse’s notes indicate the baby is unable to sit unsupported, further suggesting that pulling to stand is not yet expected.
Babbling recognizable syllables like 'mama' and 'dada' is a normal language development milestone at 9 months, demonstrating early communication skills.

clinicalPearls: Developmental milestones provide a framework for assessing a child's progress, but individual variation is normal.
Early identification of developmental delays allows for timely intervention and support.
Parent education regarding expected milestones and age-appropriate activities can promote healthy development.

questionTrap.trap: Confusing variations in crawling styles or expecting advanced motor skills too early.
questionTrap.howToOvercome: Review typical developmental milestones and consider individual variations while noting specific findings in the assessment.

mnemonic.title: S-T-C-P-B
mnemonic.expansion: Sitting briefly, Transferring, Crawling not, Pulling not, Babbling 'mama/dada'.
